references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication route (Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Stripelis et al., 2022; Malekijoo et al., 2021; Stich et al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-k (Shi et al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSC (Cui et al., 2021) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns,  FedCode primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically, FedCode involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clients’ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. Table 1 presents a concise comparison between FedCode and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Federated Settings. We control the federated settings with the following parameters: 

1) number of clients - N𝑁N, 
2) client train epochs per round - E𝐸E, and 
3) number of rounds - R𝑅R, 
4) clients’ participation rate per round - ρ𝜌\rho, 
5) client class concentration - Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p}
. In FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction: 

1) number of clusters - K𝐾K, and 
2) minimum round for codebook transfer - Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb} - 
3) compressed weights upstream transfer rate - F1subscript𝐹1F_{1}, 
4) compressed weights downstream transfer rate - F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} 
. The “wordlength” for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorch’s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in Table 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter β𝛽\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as D​i​r​(10.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a β𝛽\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cp≈0.1subscript𝐶𝑝0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader to (Kairouz et al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clients’ data in federated settings (Kairouz et al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

references: To assess the impact of different data distributions on FedCode performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Table 3 represents the highest global model accuracy achieved in settings with non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, the FedCode demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of −1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCode achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCode achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of −0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and −0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCode was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the model’s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of −2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and −2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round the FedCode approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, Figure 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore, FedCode could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clients’ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases that FedCode can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20 (He et al., 2016), MobileNet (v2) (Sandler et al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) dataset (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devices (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

Federated Settings. We control the federated settings with the following parameters: 

1) number of clients - N𝑁N, 
2) client train epochs per round - E𝐸E, and 
3) number of rounds - R𝑅R, 
4) clients’ participation rate per round - ρ𝜌\rho, 
5) client class concentration - Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p}
. In FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction: 

1) number of clusters - K𝐾K, and 
2) minimum round for codebook transfer - Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb} - 
3) compressed weights upstream transfer rate - F1subscript𝐹1F_{1}, 
4) compressed weights downstream transfer rate - F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} 
. The “wordlength” for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorch’s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in Table 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter β𝛽\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as D​i​r​(10.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a β𝛽\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cp≈0.1subscript𝐶𝑝0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader to (Kairouz et al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clients’ data in federated settings (Kairouz et al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

To assess the effectiveness of FedCode in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. We measured the DTR and model accuracy compared to standard FL. The results are presented in Tables 3(a) and 3(b), from which one may notice that FedCode effectively reduces communication costs while maintaining a high global model accuracy. Specifically, using ResNet-20 on CIFAR-10, FedCode achieved an average DTR of 14.2 and 15 with ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a highly accurate model with accuracy reductions (δ𝛿\delta-Acc) of −1.43%percent1.43-1.43\% and −1.51%percent1.51-1.51\%, respectively. Using ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, the results were similarly impressive, with FedCode achieving an average DTR of 14.6 and 15.1 for ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a comparable level of accuracy, as indicated by a δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.04%percent3.04-3.04\%, respectively. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20, FedCode achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and −0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applying FedCode to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ρ𝜌\rho=00 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the model’s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and −1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed the FedCode ’s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. It is worth noting that a similar pattern like MobileNet and ResNet-20, emerged, where FedCode achieved a DTR of 101010 with minimal impact on the accuracy of the models. From this, we conclude that FedCode can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

To assess the impact of different data distributions on FedCode performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Table 3 represents the highest global model accuracy achieved in settings with non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, the FedCode demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of −1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCode achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCode achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of −0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and −0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCode was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the model’s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of −2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and −2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in Table 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global model’s accuracy.

Table 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand, FedCode achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits between FedCode , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred in FedCode is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore, FedCode can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round the FedCode approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, Figure 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore, FedCode could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clients’ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases that FedCode can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate that FedCode achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing  FedCode with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of the FedCode for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20 (He et al., 2016), MobileNet (v2) (Sandler et al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) dataset (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devices (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

Federated Settings. We control the federated settings with the following parameters: 

1) number of clients - N𝑁N, 
2) client train epochs per round - E𝐸E, and 
3) number of rounds - R𝑅R, 
4) clients’ participation rate per round - ρ𝜌\rho, 
5) client class concentration - Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p}
. In FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction: 

1) number of clusters - K𝐾K, and 
2) minimum round for codebook transfer - Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb} - 
3) compressed weights upstream transfer rate - F1subscript𝐹1F_{1}, 
4) compressed weights downstream transfer rate - F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} 
. The “wordlength” for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorch’s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in Table 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter β𝛽\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as D​i​r​(10.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a β𝛽\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cp≈0.1subscript𝐶𝑝0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader to (Kairouz et al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clients’ data in federated settings (Kairouz et al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

To assess the effectiveness of FedCode in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. We measured the DTR and model accuracy compared to standard FL. The results are presented in Tables 3(a) and 3(b), from which one may notice that FedCode effectively reduces communication costs while maintaining a high global model accuracy. Specifically, using ResNet-20 on CIFAR-10, FedCode achieved an average DTR of 14.2 and 15 with ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a highly accurate model with accuracy reductions (δ𝛿\delta-Acc) of −1.43%percent1.43-1.43\% and −1.51%percent1.51-1.51\%, respectively. Using ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, the results were similarly impressive, with FedCode achieving an average DTR of 14.6 and 15.1 for ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a comparable level of accuracy, as indicated by a δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.04%percent3.04-3.04\%, respectively. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20, FedCode achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and −0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applying FedCode to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ρ𝜌\rho=00 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the model’s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and −1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed the FedCode ’s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. It is worth noting that a similar pattern like MobileNet and ResNet-20, emerged, where FedCode achieved a DTR of 101010 with minimal impact on the accuracy of the models. From this, we conclude that FedCode can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

To assess the impact of different data distributions on FedCode performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Table 3 represents the highest global model accuracy achieved in settings with non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, the FedCode demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of −1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCode achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCode achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of −0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and −0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCode was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the model’s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of −2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and −2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in Table 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global model’s accuracy.

Table 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand, FedCode achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits between FedCode , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred in FedCode is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore, FedCode can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round the FedCode approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, Figure 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore, FedCode could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clients’ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases that FedCode can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate that FedCode achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing  FedCode with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of the FedCode for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication route (Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Stripelis et al., 2022; Malekijoo et al., 2021; Stich et al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-k (Shi et al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSC (Cui et al., 2021) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns,  FedCode primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically, FedCode involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clients’ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. Table 1 presents a concise comparison between FedCode and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20, FedCode achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and −0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applying FedCode to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ρ𝜌\rho=00 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the model’s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and −1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed the FedCode ’s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. It is worth noting that a similar pattern like MobileNet and ResNet-20, emerged, where FedCode achieved a DTR of 101010 with minimal impact on the accuracy of the models. From this, we conclude that FedCode can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

To assess the impact of different data distributions on FedCode performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Table 3 represents the highest global model accuracy achieved in settings with non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, the FedCode demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of −1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCode achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCode achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of −0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and −0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCode was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the model’s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of −2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and −2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in Table 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global model’s accuracy.

Table 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand, FedCode achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits between FedCode , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred in FedCode is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore, FedCode can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round the FedCode approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, Figure 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore, FedCode could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clients’ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases that FedCode can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate that FedCode achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing  FedCode with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of the FedCode for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication route (Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Stripelis et al., 2022; Malekijoo et al., 2021; Stich et al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-k (Shi et al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSC (Cui et al., 2021) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns,  FedCode primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically, FedCode involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clients’ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. Table 1 presents a concise comparison between FedCode and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20 (He et al., 2016), MobileNet (v2) (Sandler et al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) dataset (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devices (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

Federated Settings. We control the federated settings with the following parameters: 

1) number of clients - N𝑁N, 
2) client train epochs per round - E𝐸E, and 
3) number of rounds - R𝑅R, 
4) clients’ participation rate per round - ρ𝜌\rho, 
5) client class concentration - Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p}
. In FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction: 

1) number of clusters - K𝐾K, and 
2) minimum round for codebook transfer - Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb} - 
3) compressed weights upstream transfer rate - F1subscript𝐹1F_{1}, 
4) compressed weights downstream transfer rate - F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} 
. The “wordlength” for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorch’s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in Table 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter β𝛽\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as D​i​r​(10.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a β𝛽\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cp≈0.1subscript𝐶𝑝0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader to (Kairouz et al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clients’ data in federated settings (Kairouz et al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

. The “wordlength” for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorch’s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in Table 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter β𝛽\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as D​i​r​(10.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a β𝛽\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cp≈0.1subscript𝐶𝑝0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader to (Kairouz et al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clients’ data in federated settings (Kairouz et al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

To assess the effectiveness of FedCode in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. We measured the DTR and model accuracy compared to standard FL. The results are presented in Tables 3(a) and 3(b), from which one may notice that FedCode effectively reduces communication costs while maintaining a high global model accuracy. Specifically, using ResNet-20 on CIFAR-10, FedCode achieved an average DTR of 14.2 and 15 with ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a highly accurate model with accuracy reductions (δ𝛿\delta-Acc) of −1.43%percent1.43-1.43\% and −1.51%percent1.51-1.51\%, respectively. Using ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, the results were similarly impressive, with FedCode achieving an average DTR of 14.6 and 15.1 for ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a comparable level of accuracy, as indicated by a δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.04%percent3.04-3.04\%, respectively. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20, FedCode achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and −0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applying FedCode to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ρ𝜌\rho=00 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the model’s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and −1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed the FedCode ’s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. It is worth noting that a similar pattern like MobileNet and ResNet-20, emerged, where FedCode achieved a DTR of 101010 with minimal impact on the accuracy of the models. From this, we conclude that FedCode can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

To assess the impact of different data distributions on FedCode performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Table 3 represents the highest global model accuracy achieved in settings with non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, the FedCode demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of −1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCode achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCode achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of −0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and −0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCode was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the model’s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of −2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and −2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in Table 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global model’s accuracy.

Table 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand, FedCode achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits between FedCode , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred in FedCode is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore, FedCode can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round the FedCode approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, Figure 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore, FedCode could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clients’ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases that FedCode can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate that FedCode achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing  FedCode with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of the FedCode for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication route (Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Stripelis et al., 2022; Malekijoo et al., 2021; Stich et al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-k (Shi et al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSC (Cui et al., 2021) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns,  FedCode primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically, FedCode involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clients’ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. Table 1 presents a concise comparison between FedCode and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20 (He et al., 2016), MobileNet (v2) (Sandler et al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) dataset (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devices (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

In response to the aforementioned concerns,  FedCode primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically, FedCode involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clients’ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. Table 1 presents a concise comparison between FedCode and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20 (He et al., 2016), MobileNet (v2) (Sandler et al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) dataset (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devices (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

Federated Settings. We control the federated settings with the following parameters: 

1) number of clients - N𝑁N, 
2) client train epochs per round - E𝐸E, and 
3) number of rounds - R𝑅R, 
4) clients’ participation rate per round - ρ𝜌\rho, 
5) client class concentration - Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p}
. In FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction: 

1) number of clusters - K𝐾K, and 
2) minimum round for codebook transfer - Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb} - 
3) compressed weights upstream transfer rate - F1subscript𝐹1F_{1}, 
4) compressed weights downstream transfer rate - F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} 
. The “wordlength” for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorch’s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rc​bsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑏R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in Table 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter β𝛽\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as D​i​r​(10.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cp≈1subscript𝐶𝑝1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a β𝛽\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cp≈0.1subscript𝐶𝑝0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader to (Kairouz et al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clients’ data in federated settings (Kairouz et al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

To assess the effectiveness of FedCode in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. We measured the DTR and model accuracy compared to standard FL. The results are presented in Tables 3(a) and 3(b), from which one may notice that FedCode effectively reduces communication costs while maintaining a high global model accuracy. Specifically, using ResNet-20 on CIFAR-10, FedCode achieved an average DTR of 14.2 and 15 with ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a highly accurate model with accuracy reductions (δ𝛿\delta-Acc) of −1.43%percent1.43-1.43\% and −1.51%percent1.51-1.51\%, respectively. Using ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, the results were similarly impressive, with FedCode achieving an average DTR of 14.6 and 15.1 for ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a comparable level of accuracy, as indicated by a δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.04%percent3.04-3.04\%, respectively. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20, FedCode achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ρ𝜌\rho=111 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and −0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applying FedCode to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ρ𝜌\rho=00 and ρ𝜌\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the model’s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving δ𝛿\delta-Acc of −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and −1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed the FedCode ’s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNet (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. It is worth noting that a similar pattern like MobileNet and ResNet-20, emerged, where FedCode achieved a DTR of 101010 with minimal impact on the accuracy of the models. From this, we conclude that FedCode can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

To assess the impact of different data distributions on FedCode performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Table 3 represents the highest global model accuracy achieved in settings with non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, the FedCode demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of −1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and −1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCode achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of −3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and −3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCode achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of −0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and −0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCode was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the model’s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of −2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and −2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ρ𝜌\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in Table 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global model’s accuracy.

Table 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZip (Malekijoo et al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand, FedCode achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits between FedCode , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred in FedCode is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore, FedCode can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round the FedCode approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, Figure 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore, FedCode could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clients’ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases that FedCode can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate that FedCode achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing  FedCode with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of the FedCode for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.
